remixlab.dandelion.core

Class InteractiveFrame

  • java.lang.Object
    • remixlab.dandelion.core.Frame
      • remixlab.dandelion.core.InteractiveFrame
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Grabber, Constants, Copyable
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    InteractiveAvatarFrame, InteractiveEyeFrame

    public class InteractiveFrame
extends Frame
implements Grabber, Copyable, Constants
    An InteractiveFrame is a Frame that can be rotated, translated and scaled by user interaction means.

    An InteractiveFrame converts user gestures into translation, rotation and scaling updates. An InteractiveFrame is used to move an object in the scene (and thus it's tightly-coupled with it). Combined with object selection, its Grabber properties and a dynamic update of the scene, the InteractiveFrame introduces a great reactivity to your dandelion-based applications.

    The possible actions that can interactively be performed by the InteractiveFrame are Constants.ClickAction, Constants.DOF1Action, Constants.DOF2Action, Constants.DOF3Action and Constants.DOF6Action. The AbstractScene.motionAgent() provides high-level methods to handle some of these actions, e.g., a MouseAgent can handle up to Constants.DOF2Actions

    Note: Once created, the InteractiveFrame is automatically added to the scene InputHandler.agents() pool.

    • Field Detail

      • dirIsFixed

        public boolean dirIsFixed

    • Constructor Detail

      • InteractiveFrame

        public InteractiveFrame(AbstractScene scn)
        Default constructor.

        The Frame.translation() is set to 0, with an identity Frame.rotation() and no Frame.scaling() (see Frame constructor for details). The different sensitivities are set to their default values (see rotationSensitivity() , translationSensitivity(), spinningSensitivity() and wheelSensitivity()). dampingFriction() is set to 0.5.

        Note: the InteractiveFrame is automatically added to the InputHandler.agents() pool.

      • InteractiveFrame

        public InteractiveFrame(AbstractScene scn,
                Frame referenceFrame)
        Same as this(scn) and then calls Frame.setReferenceFrame(Frame) on referenceFrame.

      • isInEyePath

        public boolean isInEyePath()
        Returns true if the InteractiveFrame forms part of an Eye path and false otherwise.

      • grabsInputThreshold

        public int grabsInputThreshold()
        Returns the grabs input threshold which is used by this interactive frame to checkIfGrabsInput(BogusEvent) .
        See Also:
        setGrabsInputThreshold(int)

      • setGrabsInputThreshold

        public void setGrabsInputThreshold(int threshold)
        Sets the number of pixels that defined the checkIfGrabsInput(BogusEvent) condition.
        Parameters:
        threshold - number of pixels that defined the checkIfGrabsInput(BogusEvent) condition. Default value is 10 pixels (which is set in the constructor). Negative values are silently ignored.
        See Also:
        grabsInputThreshold(), checkIfGrabsInput(BogusEvent)

      • checkIfGrabsInput

        public boolean checkIfGrabsInput(BogusEvent event)
        Implementation of the Grabber main method.

        The InteractiveFrame grabsInput(Agent) when the event coordinates is within a grabsInputThreshold() pixels region around its Eye.projectedCoordinatesOf(Vec) Frame.position().

        Specified by:
        checkIfGrabsInput in interface Grabber

        public boolean grabsInput(Agent agent)
        Returns true when this frame grabs the Scene's agent.
        Specified by:

      • rotationSensitivity

        public final float rotationSensitivity()
        Returns the influence of a gesture displacement on the InteractiveFrame rotation.

        Default value is 1.0 (which matches an identical mouse displacement), a higher value will generate a larger rotation (and inversely for lower values). A 0.0 value will forbid rotation (see also Frame.constraint()).

        See Also:
        setRotationSensitivity(float), translationSensitivity(), spinningSensitivity(), wheelSensitivity()

      • translationSensitivity

        public final float translationSensitivity()
        Returns the influence of a gesture displacement on the InteractiveFrame translation.

        Default value is 1.0 which in the case of a mouse interaction makes the InteractiveFrame precisely stays under the mouse cursor.

        With an identical gesture displacement, a higher value will generate a larger translation (and inversely for lower values). A 0.0 value will forbid translation (see also Frame.constraint()).

        See Also:
        setTranslationSensitivity(float), rotationSensitivity(), spinningSensitivity(), wheelSensitivity()

      • spinningSensitivity

        public final float spinningSensitivity()
        Returns the minimum gesture speed required to make the InteractiveFrame spin(). Spinning requires to set to dampingFriction() to 0.

        See spin(), spinningRotation() and startSpinning(MotionEvent) for details.

        Gesture speed is expressed in pixels per milliseconds. Default value is 0.3 (300 pixels per second). Use setSpinningSensitivity(float) to tune this value. A higher value will make spinning more difficult (a value of 100.0 forbids spinning in practice).

        See Also:
        setSpinningSensitivity(float), translationSensitivity(), rotationSensitivity(), wheelSensitivity(), setDampingFriction(float)

      • wheelSensitivity

        public float wheelSensitivity()
        Returns the wheel sensitivity.

        Default value is 20.0. A higher value will make the wheel action more efficient (usually meaning a faster zoom). Use a negative value to invert the zoom in and out directions.

        See Also:
        setWheelSensitivity(float), translationSensitivity(), rotationSensitivity(), spinningSensitivity()

      • isSpinning

        public final boolean isSpinning()
        Returns true when the InteractiveFrame is spinning.

        During spinning, spin() rotates the InteractiveFrame by its spinningRotation() at a frequency defined when the InteractiveFrame startSpinning(MotionEvent).

        Use startSpinning(MotionEvent) and stopSpinning() to change this state. Default value is false.

        See Also:
        isTossing()

      • isTossing

        public final boolean isTossing()
        Returns true when the InteractiveFrame is tossing.

        During tossing, toss() translates the InteractiveFrame by its tossingDirection() at a frequency defined when the InteractiveFrame startTossing(MotionEvent).

        Use startTossing(MotionEvent) and stopTossing() to change this state. Default value is false. isSpinning()

      • spinningRotation

        public final Rotation spinningRotation()
        Returns the incremental rotation that is applied by spin() to the InteractiveFrame orientation when it isSpinning().

        Default value is a null rotation. Use setSpinningRotation(Rotation) to change this value.

        The spinningRotation() axis is defined in the InteractiveFrame coordinate system. You can use Frame.transformOfFrom(Vec, Frame) to convert this axis from another Frame coordinate system.

        Attention: Spinning may be decelerated according to dampingFriction() till it stops completely.

        See Also:
        tossingDirection()

      • tossingDirection

        public final Vec tossingDirection()
        Returns the incremental translation that is applied by toss() to the InteractiveFrame position when it isTossing().

        Default value is no translation. Use setTossingDirection(Vec) to change this value.

        Attention: Tossing may be decelerated according to dampingFriction() till it stops completely.

        See Also:
        spinningRotation()

      • setSpinningRotation

        public final void setSpinningRotation(Rotation spinningRotation)
        Defines the spinningRotation(). Its axis is defined in the InteractiveFrame coordinate system.
        See Also:
        setTossingDirection(Vec)

      • setTossingDirection

        public final void setTossingDirection(Vec dir)
        Defines the tossingDirection() in the InteractiveFrame coordinate system.
        See Also:
        setSpinningRotation(Rotation)

      • isInInteraction

        public boolean isInInteraction()
        Returns true when the InteractiveFrame is being manipulated with an agent.

      • stopSpinning

        public final void stopSpinning()
        Stops the spinning motion started using startSpinning(MotionEvent). isSpinning() will return false after this call.

        Attention: This method may be called by spin(), since spinning may be decelerated according to dampingFriction() till it stops completely.

        See Also:
        dampingFriction(), toss()

      • stopTossing

        public final void stopTossing()
        Stops the tossing motion started using startTossing(MotionEvent). isTossing() will return false after this call.

        Attention: This method may be called by toss(), since tossing may be decelerated according to dampingFriction() till it stops completely.

        See Also:
        dampingFriction(), spin()

      • startSpinning

        public void startSpinning(MotionEvent e)
        Starts the spinning of the InteractiveFrame.

        This method starts a timer that will call spin() every updateInterval milliseconds. The InteractiveFrame isSpinning() until you call stopSpinning().

        Attention: Spinning may be decelerated according to dampingFriction() till it stops completely.

        See Also:
        dampingFriction(), toss()

      • startTossing

        public void startTossing(MotionEvent e)
        Starts the tossing of the InteractiveFrame.

        This method starts a timer that will call toss() every FLY_UPDATE_PERDIOD milliseconds. The InteractiveFrame isTossing() until you call stopTossing().

        Attention: Tossing may be decelerated according to dampingFriction() till it stops completely.

        See Also:
        dampingFriction(), spin()

      • spin

        public void spin()
        Rotates the InteractiveFrame by its spinningRotation(). Called by a timer when the InteractiveFrame isSpinning().

        Attention: Spinning may be decelerated according to dampingFriction() till it stops completely.

        See Also:
        dampingFriction(), toss()

      • toss

        public void toss()
        Translates the InteractiveFrame by its tossingDirection(). Invoked by a timer when the InteractiveFrame is performing the DRIVE, MOVE_BACKWARD or MOVE_FORWARD dandelion actions.

        Attention: Tossing may be decelerated according to dampingFriction() till it stops completely.

        See Also:
        spin()

      • setDampingFriction

        public void setDampingFriction(float f)
        Defines the dampingFriction(). Values must be in the range [0..1].

      • dampingFriction

        public float dampingFriction()
        Defines the spinning deceleration.

        Default value is 0.5. Use setDampingFriction(float) to tune this value. A higher value will make damping more difficult (a value of 1.0 forbids damping).

      • flySpeed

        public float flySpeed()
        Returns the fly speed, expressed in virtual scene units.

        It corresponds to the incremental displacement that is periodically applied to the InteractiveFrame position when a MOVE_FORWARD or MOVE_BACKWARD action is proceeded.

        Attention: When the InteractiveFrame is set as the Eye.frame() or when it is set as the AbstractScene.avatar() (which indeed is an instance of the InteractiveAvatarFrame class), this value is set according to the AbstractScene.radius() by AbstractScene.setRadius(float).

      • setFlySpeed

        public void setFlySpeed(float speed)
        Sets the flySpeed(), defined in virtual scene units.

        Default value is 0.0, but it is modified according to the AbstractScene.radius() when the InteractiveFrame is set as the Eye.frame() (which indeed is an instance of the InteractiveEyeFrame class) or when the InteractiveFrame is set as the AbstractScene.avatar() (which indeed is an instance of the InteractiveAvatarFrame class).

      • sceneUpVector

        public Vec sceneUpVector()
        Returns the up vector used in fly mode, expressed in the world coordinate system.

        Fly mode corresponds to the MOVE_FORWARD and MOVE_BACKWARD action bindings. In these modes, horizontal displacements of the mouse rotate the InteractiveFrame around this vector. Vertical displacements rotate always around the frame X axis.

        This value is also used within the CAD_ROTATE action to define the up vector (and incidentally the 'horizon' plane) around which the camera will rotate.

        Default value is (0,1,0), but it is updated by the Eye when set as its Eye.frame(). Eye.setOrientation(Rotation) and Eye.setUpVector(Vec) modify this value and should be used instead.

      • setSceneUpVector

        public void setSceneUpVector(Vec up)
        Sets the sceneUpVector(), defined in the world coordinate system.

        Default value is (0,1,0), but it is updated by the Eye when set as its Eye.frame(). Use Eye.setUpVector(Vec) instead in that case.

      • updateSceneUpVector

        public final void updateSceneUpVector()
        This method will be called by the Eye when its orientation is changed, so that the sceneUpVector() is changed accordingly. You should not need to call this method.

      • rotateAroundEyeAxes

        public void rotateAroundEyeAxes(float roll,
                       float pitch,
                       float yaw)
        Extrinsic rotation about the AbstractScene.eye() InteractiveEyeFrame axes.
        Parameters:
        roll - Rotation angle in radians around the Eye x-Axis
        pitch - Rotation angle in radians around the Eye y-Axis
        yaw - Rotation angle in radians around the Eye z-Axis
        See Also:
        Quat.fromEulerAngles(float, float, float)
